articles.headline: Texas Goes Permitless on Guns, and Police Face an Armed Public
articles.snippet: A new law allowing people to carry handguns without a license has led to more spontaneous shootings, many in law enforcement say.
articles.abstract: A new law allowing people to carry handguns without a license has led to more spontaneous shootings, many in law enforcement say.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Fetterman’s Debate Showing Raises Democratic Anxieties in Senate Battle
articles.snippet: The Democratic nominee’s performance in Pennsylvania thrust questions of health to the center of a pivotal Senate race, adding uncertainty to the contest and worrying some in his party.
articles.abstract: The Democratic nominee’s performance in Pennsylvania thrust questions of health to the center of a pivotal Senate race, adding uncertainty to the contest and worrying some in his party.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debate performance on Tuesday night by Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Pennsylvania, left party officials newly anxious, injecting a fresh dose of unpredictability into one of the country’s most important contests less than two weeks before Election Day.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Meta’s Profit Slides by More Than 50 Percent as Challenges Mount
articles.snippet: The social networking company, which is trying to shift into the so-called metaverse, posted falling sales and said it was “making significant changes” to operate more efficiently.
articles.abstract: The social networking company, which is trying to shift into the so-called metaverse, posted falling sales and said it was “making significant changes” to operate more efficiently.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Mark Zuckerberg changed Facebook’s name to Meta and said he was going all in on the immersive digital world of the so-called metaverse.

articles.headline: Meet Me Downtown
articles.snippet: We visited 10 cities across the country to see how the pandemic and its aftershocks have reshaped the American downtown.
articles.abstract: We visited 10 cities across the country to see how the pandemic and its aftershocks have reshaped the American downtown.
articles.lead_paragraph: We visited 10 cities across the country to see how the pandemic and its aftershocks have reshaped the American downtown.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Jack Healy, Rick Rojas, Edgar Sandoval, Julie Bosman, Eliza Fawcett, Emily Cochrane and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Tech’s Biggest Companies Are Sending Worrying Signals About the Economy
articles.snippet: A series of quarterly earnings reports is showing that even Silicon Valley’s most powerful companies are feeling the impact of inflation and rising interest rates.
articles.abstract: A series of quarterly earnings reports is showing that even Silicon Valley’s most powerful companies are feeling the impact of inflation and rising interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google this week reported a steep decline in profits. Social media companies such as Meta said that advertising sales — the heart of their businesses — have rapidly cooled off. And Microsoft, perhaps the tech industry’s most reliable performer, predicted a slowdown through at least the end of the year.

articles.headline: Putin Wants to Divide Ukrainians. Mykolaiv Is a Test Case.
articles.snippet: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
articles.abstract: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — As Elizaveta Kachuk waited in line for drinking water, a daily ritual that is not always successful, she cursed the Russians who bombed her city. But she also voiced discontent with her fellow Ukrainians still running it.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: A Rising Dollar Is Hurting Other Currencies. Central Banks Are Stepping In.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes are unsettling global markets and prompting other central banks to prop up their domestic currencies.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s interest rate hikes are unsettling global markets and prompting other central banks to prop up their domestic currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Governments around the world have sought to stabilize their currencies and defend their economies against the Federal Reserve’s rapid interest rate increases, which have tilted the field in favor of the dollar. Their efforts highlight both the interconnected nature of the global financial system and its vulnerabilities.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: How Mike Lindell’s Pillow Business Propels the Election Denial Movement
articles.snippet: Many American entrepreneurs have mixed politics and business. No one has fused the two quite like the chief executive of MyPillow.
articles.abstract: Many American entrepreneurs have mixed politics and business. No one has fused the two quite like the chief executive of MyPillow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three days after federal agents seized his cellphone as part of an investigation into voting machine tampering, Mike Lindell seemed energized and ready to sell pillows.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon, Charles Homans and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Unveils Sweeping Revamp to Revive Its Fortunes
articles.snippet: The restructuring includes shrinking its investment bank and raising $4 billion in capital from investors, including a state-owned Saudi bank.
articles.abstract: The restructuring includes shrinking its investment bank and raising $4 billion in capital from investors, including a state-owned Saudi bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: After decades of chasing the prestige and profits of its rivals on Wall Street, Credit Suisse is pulling back to save itself.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: J.D. Vance’s Ambition Comes at a Price in ‘Hillbilly’ Terms
articles.snippet: The Republican Senate candidate changed his tune on Donald Trump and now has his endorsement, but a remark by the former president about Vance’s fealty is dogging him in Ohio.
articles.abstract: The Republican Senate candidate changed his tune on Donald Trump and now has his endorsement, but a remark by the former president about Vance’s fealty is dogging him in Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio — Blue jeans evoked his hardscrabble upbringing, and a crisp dress shirt conveyed his success as a Yale Law School graduate, venture capitalist and best-selling memoirist — with the open collar signaling that he was still just J.D., who happens to be the Ohio Republican candidate for the Senate.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Returned to Growth in Third Quarter
articles.snippet: Gross domestic product increased 0.6 percent after two quarters of decline, but key components continue to show an economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: Gross domestic product increased 0.6 percent after two quarters of decline, but key components continue to show an economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy grew slowly over the summer, adding to fears of a looming recession — but also keeping alive the hope that one might be avoided.

articles.headline: U.S. Mortgage Rates Rise Past 7%
articles.snippet: The average rate on 30-year mortgages — the most popular kind among Americans — rose to the highest level since 2002, tracking the Federal Reserve’s aggressive campaign of rate increases.
articles.abstract: The average rate on 30-year mortgages — the most popular kind among Americans — rose to the highest level since 2002, tracking the Federal Reserve’s aggressive campaign of rate increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates barreled past the 7 percent mark on Thursday to their highest level since 2002, as the Federal Reserve’s aggressive interest rate increases, meant to combat inflation, continued to seep through the economy and weigh increasingly on the housing market.

articles.headline: Chip Makers, Once in High Demand, Confront Sudden Challenges
articles.snippet: Demand for semiconductors was off the charts last year. But a sharp slowdown coupled with new U.S. restrictions against China have created obstacles.
articles.abstract: Demand for semiconductors was off the charts last year. But a sharp slowdown coupled with new U.S. restrictions against China have created obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, makers of computer chips seemed on top of the world.
